I doubt if the claim being made in this video is true. It can be easily debunked with elementary physics. The process, from lifting the 10 kg weight (as in the 10 kg bag of soil) through to the light shining from an efficient LED (light emitting diode) is based entirely on a well-established and proven law of physics. It is called The Law Of Conservation Of Energy. Simply put, it means that you can't get something from nothing - or - what comes out has first to be put in.

Consider a 10 kg (22 pounds) bag of soil that has to be lifted 1 meter (3 feet 3 inches).

g, or the gravity constant is 10 (N/kg)

The force due to weight of 10 kg = F = mg = 10 x 10N = 100N

Work done to lift the bag = F x d = 100N x 1 meter = 100 joules

So the light energy that can be obtained from this simple arrangement is 100 joules.

1 watt = 1 joule/ sec, so 100 joules provides 1 watt for 100 seconds, or 10 watts for 10 seconds, or 100 watts for 1 second.

Taking into account efficiency, the power potential is the maximum that can possibly be obtained from 10 kg dropped through 1 meter.

If the electricity obtained by a generator powered by the falling bag is used to power a 1 watt LED, we'd have the following scenario:

A 1 watt LED would be powered for 100 seconds at maximum. That's 1 minute 40 seconds. Electric generators, efficient as they may appear to be, rarely reach much more than 20% efficiency overall. Even if the overall efficiency was 50%, which is an unattainable efficiency, at best, a 1 watt LED would be lit for 50 seconds using a 1 meter drop and a weight of 10 kg.

A 1 watt LED provides hardly enough light to illuminate a small room sufficient for you to see the walls. I wouldn't want to try to read a book by it. Any idea that such an arrangement would provide useful light for half an hour is far-fetched in the extreme. The ligth uses the convertion between potential enery into kinetic energy, wich then is converted by the DC generator into electricity.

Potential energy is the mass times gravity times height. This is the energy that a static object has as a potential in a gravitational field when is lifted up. when the object drops, the potential energy converts into kinetic energy, with is the half of the mass times the square of the speed at a given moment of the fall.

Converting potential energy into kinetic energy is easy: just let the object drop. But putting potential enery into an object (thus lifting the object upwards) requires an energy. And a person lifting the weigth is that energy. Human energy.

Potential energy is like a spring. It doesn't generate energy, just releases the energy stored in it.
